text: Please bring me in trend follower. The introduction of carry signals into trend is certainly something I've seen in looking at the trend space over the last couple of years. It strikes me as potentially something folks are doing as a way to help protect their portfolios better from some of the negative performance that trend has seen. I think when you look at trend strategies, they did incredibly well in 2008. They struggled for a little while when oil prices sold off and there was a bit of a commodity crash. Crash trend strategies seem to do really well again and then since have been sort of bleeding a little bit of money. I think there's been a lot of people trying to explain maybe why trend hasn't done as well in the last decade. I've seen some people saying that the inflow of capital has caused sort of the broad index. When you look at trend followers as an index, it has to slow down their signals. So prior to 2008, trend followers tended to be a lot faster in their signals. Now post with the influx of capital, they've had to slow down. To prevent higher trading costs. AQR actually recently published a piece talking about that it's really just been that magnitude, the absolute size of trends. And the post-crisis period has largely been subdued compared to the pre-crisis period. I wanted to get your perspective. Obviously you work at a trend following firm now. My guess is you don't think trend following is inherently broken. But do you think that there have been significant changes in the market environment that have caused trend following to slow down? Or do you think that there's a risk that there has been an inherent shift in market dynamics that will prevent trend following from working in the future?

segments.text: Please bring me in trend follower.
The introduction of carry signals into trend is certainly something I've seen in looking at the trend space over the last couple of years.
It strikes me as potentially something folks are doing as a way to help protect their portfolios better from some of the negative performance that trend has seen.
I think when you look at trend strategies, they did incredibly well in 2008.
They struggled for a little while when oil prices sold off and there was a bit of a commodity crash.
Crash trend strategies seem to do really well again and then since have been sort of bleeding a little bit of money.
I think there's been a lot of people trying to explain maybe why trend hasn't done as well in the last decade.
I've seen some people saying that the inflow of capital has caused sort of the broad index.
When you look at trend followers as an index, it has to slow down their signals.
So prior to 2008, trend followers tended to be a lot faster in their signals.
Now post with the influx of capital, they've had to slow down.
AQR actually recently published a piece talking about that it's really just been that magnitude, the absolute size of trends.
And the post-crisis period has largely been subdued compared to the pre-crisis period.
I wanted to get your perspective.
Obviously you work at a trend following firm now.
My guess is you don't think trend following is inherently broken.
But do you think that there have been significant changes in the market environment that have caused trend following to slow down?
Or do you think that there's a risk that there has been an inherent shift in market dynamics that will prevent trend following from working in the future?
